text_sections.section_2: To improve the website, the and set and . In doing so, the DAAD and third parties transfer usage data to is no level of data protection comparable to that under EU law. By clicking the "Accept all" button, you consent to this processing. You can also find selection options and explanations of these cookies and processing at the end of this page under "Cookies". There you can consent at any time with effect for the future.
text_sections.section_12: Germany is a safe country for international standards. The police are trustworthy and offer help whenever they are needed. All you have to do is call 110. If you have other problems, you can contact your country’s diplomatic mission in Germany.
text_sections.section_18: There is no reason to be overly worried about criminality in Germany. You can move about freely through German villages or large cities, day or night, without taking special safety precautions. Of course, Germany does have its share of crime. Therefore, you shouldn’t take any unnecessary risks – like walking alone through dark streets or in the woods at night time.
text_sections.section_20: German police are trustworthy and provide reliable assistance. The police patrol German cities on foot, by bike, motorcycle and car (or “Streifenwagen” as they’re called in Germany).
text_sections.section_22: The police are not the only ones who can assist foreign students in emergencies. Almost every country in the world maintains an embassy or consulate in Germany. If you run into problems, you can contact an official representative from your home country.
text_sections.section_23: You can find more information on the website of the  (https://www.auswaertiges-amt.de/de/ReiseUndSicherheit/vertretungen-anderer-staaten)
text_sections.section_24: And don’t hesitate to contact the staff at the International Office if you have any questions regarding personal safety or other problems.
